[[National Academy of Engineering]] | doctoral_advisor = Donald Lee Iglehart | thesis_title = Weak Convergence Theorems for Queues in Heavy Traffic{{MathGenealogy|id=51406}} | thesis_year = 1969 }} '''Ward Whitt''' (born 1942) is an [[United States|American]] professor of [[operations research]] and management sciences. He is the Wai T. Chang Professor of Industrial Engineering and Operations Research at [[Columbia University]]. His research focuses on [[queueing theory]], performance analysis, [[Stochastic process|stochastic models]] of telecommunication systems, and [[numerical transform inversion]]. He is recognized for his contributions to the understanding and analyses of complex queues and queuing networks, which led to advances in the telecommunications system.http://www.nae.edu/MembersSection/Directory20412/30236.aspx As of November 2, 2015, his publications have been cited over 25,000 times, and he has an h-index of 82.{{Cite web|url = https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=FWApsI0AAAAJ&hl=en|title = Google Scholar Record for W. Whitt|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Biography== Whitt was born in [[Bozeman, Montana]]. He received a BA in Mathematics from [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] and a PhD in operations research from [[Cornell University|Cornell]] (1969).http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1937-5956.2011.01181.x/full His doctoral thesis, Weak Convergence Theorems for Queues in Heavy Traffic, paved the path for his future research. Whitt joined the operations research faculty at [[Stanford University|Stanford]] before moving to [[Yale University|Yale]] in 1969. From 1977–2002, he worked in [[Bell Labs]] and then [[AT&T Labs]]. Since then, he has been a professor at Columbia.http://www.ieor.columbia.edu/fac-bios/whitt/faculty.html ==Honors== Whitt received numerous accolades for his seminal contributions to [[actuarial science]]. He holds a number of telecommunications-related patents.http://www.columbia.edu/~ww2040/patents.html He has been on the editorial boards of major management science journals including [[Operations Research (journal)|''Operations Research'']]. He is a member of [[Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences]] (INFORMS) and [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]. He has also been a member and committee chair in the [[National Academy of Engineering]]. From 1999 to 2001, Whitt has been on the INFORMS prize committee.http://www.columbia.edu/~ww2040/activities.html ==Awards== *2003 INFORMS [[Frederick W.
